Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Terahertz Vector Network Analyzer as a Regional Resource for Multidisciplinary Research and Training in Southern Colorado Region

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to build institutional terahertz research capacity and capabilities through the acquisition of a terahertz vector network analyzer. The proposed instrument measures network parameters of the electrical circuit and provides information regarding S-parameters, noise figure, gain compression, intermodulation, harmonic distortion, conversion gain/loss, and signal integrity information of the device, components, and materials.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the program is enabling terahertz research and research training in various areas including high power terahertz device, terahertz tunable components and materials, terahertz magnetic nanostructures, terahertz antiferromagnetic material, bio tissue characterization, terahertz imaging, and terahertz active materials research. Promising basic research concepts in terahertz area can be experimentally demonstrated which will lead to innovations and advancement of terahertz technology.

Broader impact: The broader impacts of the program include enabling research and education in terahertz frequency range and bringing community together through the increased access to the instrument from various entities. By engaging five major universities in Colorado, research collaboration in terahertz technology will lead to a new area of multidisciplinary basic research and education. Through instrument share, educational and research opportunities for southern Colorado residents including ethnic minority and women can be increased where there is a large educational achievement gap between different ethnicity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1) Two gradaute students pursuing Ph.D. dessertation on  design, fabrication and characterization of differential  band stop filter and band pass filter using the differential network analyzer acquired through the MRI grant. Differential filters have less noise than single ended filters for mixed signal application. Working with this network anlayzer gives students unique ability and skills required for industry.

2) Students are also working on differential tunable band pass filter and band pass filters using the tunable varactors such as diodes and ferroelectric capacitors. There are no published papers to our knowledge on differential filter design with ferroelectric capacitors. We will present our results in this area in the near future.

3) We are also working with University of Porto Rico, on charcaterizing the BTO/BST superlattice hetero structures in terahertz frequencies with the acquired network analyzer. University of Porto Rico has expertize on fabrication of superlattice structures with pulsed laser deposition and we will characterize them at terahertz frequencies.

4) We are also working on swiching resistor memory with nickel oxide resistors. We will charcaterize them  in terahertz frequncies in the near future.

5) We are also planning to use network analyzer to for multiband antennas, filters etc. with switching NiO resistors.

6) Two graduate students have employed the acquired terahertz network analyzer for biological tissue characterization. This experiment resulted in two conference papers and one MSEE thesis. One of the MSEE student is continuing his study into PhD degree.

7) Collaboration with Univ. of Colorado at Denver (CU Denver), Anschutz Medical Campus was formed during the biological tissue characterization. CU Denver provided precious normal and cancerous human skin samples from their tissue bank.

8) The acquired terahertz network analyzer is currently being used for various high frequency component characterization including antennas, filter, and couplers.
